landlord_tenant_relationship.reasoning: Pleadings allege a tenancy: Plaintiff rents the basement unit at 24-26 Elm Street, pays $1,200/month, is a month-to-month tenant, and Defendant is the owner/landlord (¶¶1–3, 6). These facts establish a landlord-tenant relationship.

act_or_omission_by_landlord.reasoning: Complaint alleges affirmative omissions and conduct by Defendant: failure to timely repair water intrusion after notice (¶¶8–9, 13, 19(a)), and retaliatory statements about non-renewal (¶¶14, 19(d)). These are acts/omissions attributable to the landlord.

substantial_interference.reasoning: Facts describe ongoing water intrusion, dampness, code deficiencies documented by City inspection, damage to personal property, and need to run a dehumidifier continuously—facts that plead more than minor annoyance and that materially interfere with use and enjoyment (¶¶10–12, 15, 20).

causation.reasoning: Complaint links Defendant’s failure to remediate after notice to continuing water intrusion and resulting harms (Plaintiff notified Defendant; Defendant failed to timely repair; water intrusion persisted causing property damage and higher utility costs) and cites the City inspection corroborating the condition (¶¶8–11, 13, 20).

damages.reasoning: Plaintiff alleges specific pecuniary damages (≈$400 property loss, increased utility costs, mitigation expenses) and non‑pecuniary harms (emotional distress, loss of use) and seeks compensatory relief (¶¶11–12, 21–24).
